The notice can compel the Person Under Investigation or any other person, regardless of their connection to the investigation, to attend the interview at a specified time and place. This ensures that the Investigator can gather necessary information and conduct a thorough investigation. The requirement to attend an interview is part of a broader set of powers that include producing documents, providing information, and permitting entry to business premises for document inspection. These powers are designed to facilitate comprehensive investigative processes, ensuring that all relevant information is accessible to the Investigator as required [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] and permitted [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf].
rag_answer: The Investigator may require an individual, whether or not they are the Person Under Investigation, to attend an interview and answer questions under specific conditions. This power is granted under section 206(1)(a) of the FSMR, which allows the Investigator to issue a written notice mandating attendance at a specified time and place for the purpose of an investigation [#P:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] [#P:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf]. During the interview, the Investigator can give directions regarding who may be present, require the interviewee to answer questions relevant to the investigation, and may also require the interviewee to swear an oath or give an affirmation that their answers will be true [#P:ef496cab-acc6-48a8-ab8f-f6db5b09e0b2] [#P:9be0d5ed-c413-4c81-8787-5835f4eb93d1]. The interview is conducted in private, and the Investigator can prevent any person present from disclosing information provided or questions asked during the interview [#P:9be0d5ed-c413-4c81-8787-5835f4eb93d1]. These measures ensure the integrity and confidentiality of the investigation process.

question: When can the Investigator make someone go to an interview and answer questions, even if they aren't the main person being investigated?
gold_answer: The Investigator can require someone to go to an interview and answer questions if they send a written notice. This can happen whether the person is the main focus of the investigation or not. The notice will tell the person when and where to go for the interview. This is part of the Investigator's powers to make sure they can get all the information needed for the investigation. Besides interviews, the Investigator can also ask for documents, information, and even visit business places to check documents. These actions help the Investigator do a complete job by making sure they have access to all the necessary details as required [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] and permitted [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf].
rag_answer: The Investigator has the authority to require any person, not just the main person under investigation, to attend an interview and answer questions as part of an investigation. This power is granted under section 206(1)(a) of the FSMR, which allows the Investigator to issue a written notice compelling a person to attend an interview at a specified time and place [#P:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf][#P:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. The Investigator can also direct who may be present during the interview, prevent disclosure of information, and require the interviewee to swear an oath or affirmation to provide truthful answers [#P:ef496cab-acc6-48a8-ab8f-f6db5b09e0b2]. While the interviewee is entitled to legal representation, there may be situations where a specific legal representative is deemed inappropriate due to potential conflicts of interest [#P:f98155f9-7ed6-4933-8087-b13eb4161b16]. This ensures that the investigation can proceed effectively and without undue influence or bias.

question: Under what conditions may the Investigator require an Issuer or any other person to provide relevant information or documents during an investigation?
gold_answer: During an investigation, the Investigator is empowered to obtain relevant information and/or documents either on a compulsory or voluntary basis. The Investigator may issue a written notice requiring the Person Under Investigation or any other person, regardless of their connection to the investigation, to comply with specific procedural steps. These steps include attending an interview at a specified time and place, producing specified documents, providing required information, offering necessary assistance, or permitting entry to business premises for document inspection and copying. This procedural authority ensures that the Investigator can effectively gather the necessary information to conduct a thorough investigation, as required [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] and permitted [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4].
rag_answer: The Investigator may require an Issuer or any other person to provide relevant information or documents during an investigation under specific conditions. Firstly, the Investigator must reasonably consider the requested information or documents to be relevant to the purposes of the investigation [#P:7a5481df-9205-4b13-85d9-3c5b66a3cf74]. The Investigator can obtain this information or documents either on a compulsory basis, primarily through the exercise of powers under section 206(1)(b) and (c) of the FSMR, or on a voluntary basis [#P:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4]. The Investigator may issue a written notice requiring the person to attend an interview, produce specified documents, provide information, or permit entry to business premises for document inspection [#P:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. If a person is unable to produce a document, the Investigator may require them to state, to the best of their knowledge, where the document may be found and who last had possession of it [#P:e32d2f68-b3a1-49c3-8765-ba2e9437f595]. These measures ensure that the investigation is thorough and that all relevant information is accessible to the Investigator.

question: How can the Investigator get important documents or information from someone during an investigation?
gold_answer: The Investigator can ask for important documents or information during an investigation by sending a written notice. This notice can require the Person Under Investigation or anyone else, even if they are not directly involved, to do several things. They might have to attend an interview, bring certain documents, give specific information, help in other ways, or allow the Investigator to visit their business during normal hours to look at and copy documents. This process helps the Investigator gather all the needed details to carry out the investigation properly, using both compulsory and voluntary methods as allowed [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4] and required [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].
rag_answer: The Investigator can obtain important documents or information during an investigation by utilizing specific powers granted under the regulatory framework. These powers allow the Investigator to compel the production of documents and information or to obtain them voluntarily. The Investigator may issue a written notice requiring the person under investigation or any other relevant person to attend an interview, produce specified documents, provide necessary information, or offer assistance as needed [#P:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Additionally, the Investigator has the authority to enter business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy documents. This includes requiring any appropriate person to make available relevant information stored at the premises or to convert it into a physical form for copying. The Investigator may also use the facilities of the occupier of the premises to make copies, free of charge [#P:f532338d-345e-4a5e-89c2-8623a18e0fa0]. These powers are primarily exercised under sections 206(1)(b) and (c) of the FSMR, allowing the Investigator to obtain information on a compulsory basis [#P:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4]. This structured approach ensures that the Investigator can effectively gather necessary information to support the investigation.

question: Under what circumstances may an Investigator require a person to provide assistance, and what procedural steps must be followed to ensure compliance with such a requirement?
gold_answer: An Investigator is empowered to require a person to provide assistance in relation to an investigation, as outlined in the relevant regulatory framework. This authority extends to requiring a person to perform physical acts or furnish information that advances the investigation. Procedurally, the Investigator must issue a written notice to the individual, who may be the Person Under Investigation or any other person, regardless of their connection to the investigation. The notice can mandate attendance at an interview, the production of documents, or the provision of necessary information. Additionally, the Investigator may require the person to permit entry to business premises for document inspection and copying during normal business hours. These procedural steps ensure that the Investigator's powers are exercised within the defined scope and that the required assistance is obtained in a structured manner [#SRC:c595f91e-fb49-45e1-9dd6-7a847f54df95] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].
rag_answer: An Investigator may require a person to provide assistance in relation to an investigation under specific circumstances, as empowered by Section 206(1)(d) of the FSMR. This assistance can include performing a physical act or providing information necessary to advance the investigation, such as helping locate specific documents [#P:c595f91e-fb49-45e1-9dd6-7a847f54df95]. The procedural steps to ensure compliance with such a requirement include issuing a written notice to the person, specifying the assistance required. The Investigator may also require the person to attend an interview, produce documents, or permit entry to business premises for document inspection [#P:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Once a requirement is issued, the Investigator typically does not grant extensions for compliance unless compelling reasons are provided [#P:dcbcb7d5-3472-468c-84fa-d15f43ab5134]. During interviews, the Investigator can direct who may be present, restrict disclosure of information, and require the interviewee to swear an oath or affirmation to ensure truthful answers [#P:ef496cab-acc6-48a8-ab8f-f6db5b09e0b2]. These steps ensure that the investigation proceeds efficiently and that the required assistance is provided in a timely manner.

question: When can an Investigator make someone help with an investigation, and what steps do they need to take to make sure it happens?
gold_answer: An Investigator can require someone to help with an investigation if it's necessary to move the investigation forward. This can include asking the person to do something physical or give information. To make sure this happens, the Investigator must send a written notice to the person. This person could be the one being investigated or someone else, even if they're not directly involved. The notice can tell the person to come for an interview, bring certain documents, or give needed information. The Investigator can also ask to enter business premises during normal hours to look at and copy documents. These steps make sure the Investigator's request is clear and followed properly [#SRC:c595f91e-fb49-45e1-9dd6-7a847f54df95] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].
rag_answer: An Investigator can require a person to assist with an investigation by issuing a written notice that specifies the assistance needed. This power is granted under section 206(1)(d) of the FSMR, which allows the Investigator to compel a person to perform physical acts or provide information that advances the investigation, such as locating specific documents [#P:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046][#P:c595f91e-fb49-45e1-9dd6-7a847f54df95]. The Investigator must clearly outline the assistance required in the written notice, ensuring that the person understands their obligations. The notice should specify the time and place for any required actions, such as attending an interview or producing documents [#P:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. There are no specific timing or record-keeping requirements mentioned, but the notice must be clear and precise to ensure compliance. There are no stated exceptions or edge cases in the provided context, so the Investigator's powers are broad, provided they adhere to the procedural requirements outlined.

question: Under what conditions may an Investigator enter business premises to inspect documents, and how does this relate to requiring individuals to permit entry during normal business hours?
gold_answer: An Investigator is permitted to enter business premises to inspect and copy documents when it is relevant to an investigation. This authority is granted under specific regulatory provisions, allowing the Investigator to perform such actions where necessary. Additionally, the Investigator may issue a written notice requiring the Person Under Investigation or any other relevant individual to permit entry to their business premises during normal business hours for the same purpose of inspecting and copying documents. This dual authority ensures that the Investigator can effectively gather necessary information and evidence by accessing business premises and documents as required [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] and permitted [#SRC:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767].
rag_answer: An Investigator may enter business premises to inspect and copy documents under specific conditions as outlined in the regulatory framework. The Investigator is empowered to enter premises during normal business hours if it is necessary for the purposes of an investigation, as specified in a written notice to the person under investigation or any other relevant person. This entry is for the purpose of inspecting and copying documents relevant to the investigation [#P:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. When exercising this power, the Investigator can require any appropriate person to make available any relevant information stored at the premises for inspection or copying, and to convert such information into a form capable of being copied [#P:b96ffe87-e2fd-46b4-bca9-a7602c4f03ea]. Additionally, the Investigator may use the facilities of the occupier of the premises, free of charge, to make copies [#P:f532338d-345e-4a5e-89c2-8623a18e0fa0]. These provisions ensure that the Investigator can effectively gather necessary information while respecting the operational hours and resources of the business premises involved.

question: Under what conditions may an Investigator enter business premises to inspect and copy documents, and what are the requirements for notifying the Person Under Investigation or other relevant persons?
gold_answer: An Investigator is permitted to enter business premises to inspect and copy documents as part of their investigative powers. This action can be taken without prior notice if the Investigator believes that providing such notice might compromise the investigation. However, the Investigator must issue a written notice when requiring the Person Under Investigation or any other relevant person to comply with specific requests, such as attending an interview, producing documents, or providing information and assistance. This notice ensures that the person is aware of the Investigator's requirements and the specified time and place for compliance. The Investigator's authority to enter premises during normal business hours is part of their broader powers to gather necessary information and documents, ensuring that investigations are conducted effectively and without undue delay. These measures are designed to balance the need for thorough investigations with the rights of individuals and entities involved [#SRC:36b4de81-9f09-4450-8fef-1fa5c5094980] and [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].
rag_answer: An Investigator may enter business premises to inspect and copy documents under specific conditions as outlined in the regulatory framework. The Investigator must issue a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or any other relevant person, regardless of their connection to the investigation, requiring them to permit entry during normal business hours for the purpose of inspecting and copying documents on the premises [#P:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. This power is granted under Section 206(1)(e) of the FSMR, which allows entry when it is relevant for the purposes of the investigation [#P:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767]. Once on the premises, the Investigator can require any appropriate person to make available or convert relevant information into a form capable of being copied, and may use the facilities of the occupier free of charge to make copies [#P:b96ffe87-e2fd-46b4-bca9-a7602c4f03ea]. These procedures ensure that the Investigator can effectively gather necessary information while maintaining a structured and transparent process.

question: What are the prohibitions for a person who deliberately or recklessly provides false or misleading information in purported compliance with a requirement under this Part?
gold_answer: A person is prohibited from providing information that is false or misleading in a material particular, whether knowingly or recklessly, when purportedly complying with a requirement under this Part. This prohibition is crucial to ensure the integrity of the compliance process. Deliberate or reckless provision of such information constitutes a contravention of the relevant regulatory framework. The regulations explicitly prohibit any conduct that obstructs the exercise of investigative powers, which includes providing false or misleading information. This ensures that the regulatory body can effectively carry out its duties without being misled or hindered by inaccurate information. The emphasis on both deliberate and reckless actions underscores the importance of accuracy and honesty in compliance-related communications. Such prohibitions are designed to maintain trust and reliability in the regulatory process, ensuring that all parties adhere to the highest standards of truthfulness and accuracy as required [#TGT:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96] and permitted [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23].
rag_answer: A person is prohibited from deliberately or recklessly providing false or misleading information in purported compliance with a requirement under the relevant regulatory framework. Specifically, a person must not provide information that they know to be false or misleading in a material particular, nor should they recklessly provide such information [#P:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96]. This prohibition applies to any requirement where the person is expected to provide information to the Regulator, and knowingly or recklessly giving false or misleading information in this context constitutes a contravention of the regulations [#P:0393694c-3ec5-47ab-8415-dd285dde4219]. The regulations emphasize the importance of accuracy and honesty in all statements made in documents, materials, evidence, or information required by the Regulator, as any false or misleading statement, or omission of a material fact that renders the statement misleading, is considered a contravention [#P:91e34659-af3a-42b2-ba89-965c8baa6aec]. These provisions ensure that the integrity of the information provided to the Regulator is maintained, thereby supporting the regulatory framework's effectiveness and reliability.

question: What must a person not do when giving information under a requirement if they know it might be false or misleading?
gold_answer: A person must not provide information that they know is false or misleading, or do so recklessly, when they are supposed to be complying with a requirement. This rule is important to make sure that all information given is accurate and truthful. If someone deliberately or carelessly gives false or misleading information, it is considered a serious violation of the rules. The regulations are clear that such actions are not allowed because they can interfere with the work of the regulatory body. This ensures that the regulatory body can do its job properly without being misled by incorrect information. The rules focus on both deliberate and careless actions to make sure everyone is honest and careful when providing information. These prohibitions help keep the regulatory process trustworthy and reliable, making sure everyone follows the rules for truthfulness and accuracy as required [#TGT:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96] and permitted [#SRC:c683e8e0-a941-4392-901c-452854b61c23].
rag_answer: When providing information under a requirement, a person must not knowingly or recklessly provide information that is false or misleading in a material particular. This obligation is crucial to ensure the integrity and reliability of information provided in compliance with regulatory requirements. Specifically, a person is prohibited from giving information that they know to be false or misleading, or from doing so recklessly, which implies a disregard for the truth or accuracy of the information being provided [#P:77f73737-390b-4344-848c-df4d94932e96]. Additionally, if a person did not know that the information was false or misleading and could not have known it even with the exercise of all due diligence, they are not considered to have contravened this requirement [#P:ae2234cd-34c4-4630-9230-48f55f56a2b5]. This exception underscores the importance of due diligence in verifying the accuracy of information before submission. Therefore, individuals must ensure that they verify the accuracy of the information they provide and exercise due diligence to avoid any potential contravention of these requirements.

question: Under what circumstances may an Issuer or Applicant refer a decision by the Regulator to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review, considering the potential impact on rights or liabilities?
gold_answer: An Issuer or Applicant may refer a decision made by the Regulator to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review if the decision affects their rights or liabilities or adversely impacts their interests. This is applicable to any decision under the Regulations or Rules made by the Regulator, except for operational decisions. The FSMR outlines that all decisions with such impacts, including those not subject to the Part 21 procedure, such as the exercise of Own-Initiative Powers, are eligible for referral. This ensures that affected parties have a recourse to challenge decisions that may have significant implications on their legal standing or interests. The process is designed to provide a comprehensive review of the merits of the decision, ensuring fairness and accountability in regulatory actions [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea] and [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23].
rag_answer: An Issuer or Applicant may refer a decision by the Regulator to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review if the decision affects their rights or liabilities or otherwise adversely affects their interests. This is applicable to decisions made under the Regulations or Rules by the Regulator, as well as executive decisions made by a sub-panel of the Appeals Panel consisting of one member [#P:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23][#P:695442a0-f6fb-4de0-a04b-41f50780ff4f]. The right to refer such decisions is grounded in Section 225(1) of the FSMR, which explicitly allows for a full merits review by the Appeals Panel, except for operational decisions [#P:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]. Additionally, if the Regulator decides not to approve a person as a Controller or imposes conditions on such an approval, the affected person may also refer the matter to the Appeals Panel for review [#P:60c3cc10-a32b-4474-a44f-3373e884b37a]. This process ensures that decisions impacting the rights or interests of individuals or entities are subject to a comprehensive review, providing a mechanism for accountability and fairness in regulatory actions.

question: When can a person ask the Appeals Panel to review a decision by the Regulator that affects their rights or liabilities?
gold_answer: A person can ask the Appeals Panel to review a decision by the Regulator if it affects their rights or liabilities or negatively impacts their interests. This applies to any decision made under the Regulations or Rules by the Regulator, except for operational decisions. The FSMR specifies that such decisions, including those not covered by the Part 21 procedure, like the Regulator's Own-Initiative Powers, can be referred for a full merits review. This means that if a decision has a significant effect on a person's legal rights or interests, they have the option to challenge it through a thorough review process. This ensures that individuals have a way to contest decisions that might adversely affect them, promoting fairness and transparency in regulatory practices [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea] and [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23].
rag_answer: A person can request the Appeals Panel to review a decision by the Regulator that affects their rights or liabilities when such a decision is made under the Regulations or Rules established by the Regulator. This includes any decision that may adversely affect the interests of the person involved. The process for seeking a review is initiated by referring the matter to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review. This right to appeal is applicable in various scenarios, such as when the Regulator decides not to approve a person as a Controller, imposes conditions on an approval, or requires a person to dispose of their holdings. In these cases, the affected person has the right to refer the decision to the Appeals Panel for review. The Appeals Panel serves as a mechanism to ensure that decisions made by the Regulator are fair and just, providing an opportunity for the affected party to have the decision re-evaluated. This process is crucial for maintaining transparency and accountability within the regulatory framework. [#P:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23] [#P:1986a070-d683-4efa-bd13-b4bf96101b78]

question: Under what conditions may the Appeals Panel order a party to pay costs in proceedings, and how are these costs enforceable?
gold_answer: The Appeals Panel is permitted to order a party involved in proceedings to pay a specified amount covering all or part of the costs incurred during the proceedings. This authority applies to proceedings before the Appeals Panel, as well as those commenced under specific sections of the regulations. The order can include costs of any party involved in the proceedings or reference. Importantly, any costs ordered under this provision are enforceable as a civil debt, ensuring that the financial obligations imposed by the Appeals Panel are legally binding and can be pursued through civil enforcement mechanisms. This enforceability underscores the seriousness of the cost orders and provides a clear legal pathway for recovering such costs. The Appeals Panel generally seeks costs in cases where its decision is upheld, reflecting a consistent approach to cost recovery in upheld decisions [#SRC:fefc3e99-5697-4eb6-a568-b1322143a913] and [#TGT:0004e77f-2f53-45e8-9aab-1bcc7a8f88b5].
rag_answer: The Appeals Panel may order a party to pay costs in proceedings under specific conditions, and these costs are enforceable as a civil debt. The Appeals Panel can make such an order at the conclusion of proceedings commenced under sections 226 and 227 of the FSMR, requiring a party to pay a specified amount, which may include all or part of the costs of the proceedings, including those of any party involved [#P:0004e77f-2f53-45e8-9aab-1bcc7a8f88b5]. Additionally, the Appeals Panel will generally seek costs in matters referred to it where the decision of the Regulator has been upheld [#P:fefc3e99-5697-4eb6-a568-b1322143a913]. This means that if the Appeals Panel supports the Regulator's decision, it is likely to order the losing party to cover the costs. These costs are enforceable as a civil debt, ensuring that the ordered party is legally obligated to pay [#P:0004e77f-2f53-45e8-9aab-1bcc7a8f88b5].

question: When can the Appeals Panel make someone pay costs, and how are these costs treated legally?
gold_answer: The Appeals Panel can make a party pay costs at the end of certain proceedings. This can happen in cases before the Appeals Panel or those started under specific sections. The costs can cover all or part of the expenses of the proceedings, including those of any party involved. These costs are treated seriously because they are enforceable as a civil debt. This means that if someone is ordered to pay, the costs can be collected through legal means, just like any other debt. The Appeals Panel usually asks for costs when their decision is upheld, showing they often seek to recover costs in such situations [#SRC:fefc3e99-5697-4eb6-a568-b1322143a913] and [#TGT:0004e77f-2f53-45e8-9aab-1bcc7a8f88b5].
rag_answer: The Appeals Panel can order a party to pay costs in proceedings when certain conditions are met. Specifically, the Appeals Panel may require a party to pay a specified amount, which could be all or part of the costs of the proceedings, including those of any party involved, upon the conclusion of the proceedings. This is typically pursued when the decision of the Appeals Panel is upheld [#P:fefc3e99-5697-4eb6-a568-b1322143a913]. Additionally, if a person is found by the Appeals Panel or the Court to have contravened the Financial Services and Markets Regulations (FSMR) or related rules, they may be ordered to pay or reimburse the costs and expenses of the investigation, which includes the remuneration of individuals involved in the investigation [#P:b3a79331-dd20-4b2a-9efb-9441254c36d4]. These costs are treated as a legal obligation for the party found in contravention or whose appeal is unsuccessful, ensuring that the financial burden of the proceedings or investigation is appropriately allocated.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator suspend an Authorised Person's Financial Services Permission for a period deemed appropriate?
gold_answer: The Regulator is permitted to suspend an Authorised Person's Financial Services Permission for a period it considers appropriate if it determines that the Authorised Person has committed a contravention of the relevant regulations. This power to suspend is part of the broader authority to impose limitations or restrictions on the carrying on of a Regulated Activity by the Authorised Person. The suspension or imposition of restrictions is contingent upon the Regulator's assessment of the contravention and is exercised to ensure compliance with the regulatory framework. The decision to suspend or impose restrictions is made with the intention of addressing the specific contravention and is tailored to the circumstances of the case, allowing the Regulator to enforce regulatory standards effectively [#SRC:163eb2a3-8e82-4b04-bebe-bb30b95c1816] [#TGT:686dd87c-09bf-40c9-abf8-784e9ad0fd74].
rag_answer: The Regulator may suspend an Authorised Person's Financial Services Permission if it considers that the Authorised Person has committed a contravention of the regulations. This suspension can be for a period that the Regulator deems appropriate. The key precondition for such a suspension is the determination by the Regulator that a contravention has occurred. The suspension is a discretionary action, meaning the Regulator has the authority to decide the duration and terms based on the specifics of the contravention. This measure is part of the Regulator's broader powers to ensure compliance and maintain the integrity of the financial system by imposing necessary limitations or restrictions on the Authorised Person's ability to carry on a Regulated Activity. There are no specific timing or notification requirements mentioned in the context provided, nor are there any exceptions or edge cases explicitly outlined. The Regulator's decision to suspend is based on its assessment of the situation and the need to address the contravention effectively. [#P:686dd87c-09bf-40c9-abf8-784e9ad0fd74]

question: When can the Regulator suspend an Authorised Person's permission to do financial services?
gold_answer: The Regulator can suspend an Authorised Person's permission to conduct financial services if it believes the person has broken the rules. This suspension can last for as long as the Regulator thinks is right. The Regulator has the power to either suspend the permission or put limits on how the Authorised Person can carry out their activities. This is done to make sure that the rules are followed properly. The decision to suspend or limit activities is based on the specific situation and the nature of the rule-breaking. This approach helps the Regulator maintain control and ensure that all activities are conducted within the legal framework [#SRC:163eb2a3-8e82-4b04-bebe-bb30b95c1816] [#TGT:686dd87c-09bf-40c9-abf8-784e9ad0fd74].
rag_answer: The Regulator can suspend an Authorised Person's permission to conduct financial services if it determines that the person has committed a contravention of the regulations. This suspension can be for a period deemed appropriate by the Regulator. [#P:686dd87c-09bf-40c9-abf8-784e9ad0fd74] The power to suspend a Financial Services Permission is explicitly recognized, allowing the Regulator to take such action to ensure compliance and uphold regulatory standards. [#P:81d29f2e-65ff-48e1-9ace-d77a9c60e0a3] The suspension is a regulatory tool used to address and rectify non-compliance, ensuring that the Authorised Person cannot continue the regulated activity until the issues are resolved. This measure is part of a broader set of regulatory actions that can include imposing limitations or other restrictions on the Authorised Person's activities. [#P:686dd87c-09bf-40c9-abf8-784e9ad0fd74] The Regulator's decision to suspend is based on its assessment of the contravention and the necessity to protect the integrity of the financial system. There are no specific timing or notification requirements detailed in the provided context, but the suspension is intended to be a temporary measure until compliance is achieved.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator suspend an Approved Person's Approval for performing a Controlled Function, and for how long can this suspension last?
gold_answer: The Regulator is permitted to suspend an Approved Person's Approval for performing a Controlled Function if it determines that the individual has committed a contravention of the relevant regulations. This suspension can be enacted for a period deemed appropriate by the Regulator. The authority to impose such a suspension is grounded in the Regulator's power to manage approvals, which includes the ability to withdraw or vary them as necessary. The decision to suspend is contingent upon the Regulator's assessment of the contravention's nature and the circumstances surrounding it. This ensures that the suspension period aligns with the severity and implications of the contravention, thereby maintaining regulatory compliance and integrity within the controlled functions. The Regulator's discretion in determining the suspension period underscores its role in upholding the standards set forth in the regulations [#SRC:0e3409de-bae2-4891-a1dd-ef357ff5bb89] and [#TGT:5a34c2af-ed89-455c-8d46-645e7c8306d4].
rag_answer: The Regulator may suspend an Approved Person's Approval for performing a Controlled Function if it considers that the individual has committed a contravention of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations (FSMR). This suspension can last for a period deemed appropriate by the Regulator, as there is no fixed duration specified, allowing flexibility based on the severity of the contravention and other relevant factors [#P:5a34c2af-ed89-455c-8d46-645e7c8306d4][#P:0e3409de-bae2-4891-a1dd-ef357ff5bb89]. The suspension is part of the Regulator's broader powers, which also include the ability to withdraw or vary an Approved Person’s Approval [#P:0e3409de-bae2-4891-a1dd-ef357ff5bb89]. If an individual's Controlled Function is withdrawn or varied, the Authorised Person must notify the Regulator in writing within 10 days of such action [#P:05635b20-d9cb-455a-ab85-cc8d86512224]. This ensures that the Regulator is kept informed of any changes in the status of Approved Persons and can take further action if necessary. The process underscores the importance of compliance and the Regulator's role in maintaining the integrity of financial services by monitoring and addressing contraventions effectively.

question: When can the Regulator suspend an Approved Person's Approval, and how long can this suspension be?
gold_answer: The Regulator can suspend an Approved Person's Approval to perform a Controlled Function if it believes the person has broken the rules. This decision helps ensure that the rules are followed and that the performance of Controlled Functions remains trustworthy. The ability to suspend is part of the Regulator's broader powers to manage approvals, including changing or taking them away if needed. This approach allows the Regulator to respond appropriately to different situations and maintain high standards in the industry [#SRC:0e3409de-bae2-4891-a1dd-ef357ff5bb89] and [#TGT:5a34c2af-ed89-455c-8d46-645e7c8306d4].

question: Under what conditions must the Regulator disqualify an auditor or actuary from serving an Authorised Person or Recognised Body, considering the procedural steps involved?
gold_answer: The Regulator must consider disqualifying an auditor or actuary if it determines that a contravention of the regulations has occurred. The decision-making process involves evaluating the nature and seriousness of the contravention, its impact on customers, and any potential damage to the reputation of the ADGM. Additionally, the Regulator will assess whether the contravention has increased the risk of financial crime within a firm, Recognised Body, or Reporting Entity. The Regulator also considers any remedial actions taken by the auditor or actuary, as well as any disciplinary measures imposed by relevant professional bodies. The auditor's or actuary's previous compliance record and any past disciplinary sanctions are also taken into account. If these considerations lead the Regulator to conclude that the contravention is significant, it may proceed with disqualification from acting for any Authorised Person, Recognised Body, or Reporting Entity, or any specific class thereof, as required [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e] and permitted [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22].
rag_answer: The Regulator must disqualify an auditor or actuary from serving an Authorised Person or Recognised Body if it determines that the auditor or actuary has committed a contravention of the relevant regulations. The decision to disqualify involves considering several factors, including the nature and seriousness of the contravention, its impact, and any remedial actions taken by the auditor or actuary. [#P:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e] The Regulator will also assess whether the contravention has led to or is likely to lead to customer loss, damage to the ADGM's reputation, or an increased risk of financial crime. [#P:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22] Additionally, the Regulator will consider any disciplinary actions taken by relevant professional bodies and the auditor or actuary's previous compliance record. [#P:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22] There is no explicit procedural step or timing requirement mentioned for the disqualification process, but the decision will be based on a comprehensive evaluation of the circumstances surrounding the contravention. [#P:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22]

question: When can the Regulator stop an auditor or actuary from working with an Authorised Person or Recognised Body, and what steps do they follow?
gold_answer: The Regulator can stop an auditor or actuary from working with an Authorised Person or Recognised Body if they find that the auditor or actuary has broken the rules. They also check if the rule-breaking has made it more likely for financial crime to happen. They also look at the auditor's or actuary's past behavior and any past punishments. If these checks show that the rule-breaking is serious, the Regulator may decide to stop them from working with any Authorised Person, Recognised Body, or Reporting Entity, or any specific group of them, as required [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e] and permitted [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22].

[#P:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e] This action is taken to ensure compliance and maintain the integrity of financial reporting and auditing processes. Additionally, Authorised Persons and Recognised Bodies are required to notify the Regulator if they become aware or suspect that their auditor or audit staff are no longer independent or have a conflict of interest that could impair their judgment. [#P:84d9d1e2-b8a9-4f2f-a71d-813423726b5c] This notification obligation helps the Regulator monitor and address potential issues of independence or conflicts of interest proactively. The Regulator's ability to disqualify auditors or actuaries and the requirement for notification are part of a broader framework to ensure effective supervision and uphold the standards of financial and actuarial reporting. [#P:cf172ca0-5d41-47e1-92ef-72e3f975d7f1]

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator vary or revoke a Prohibition Order, and what procedural steps must an individual follow to apply for such a change?
gold_answer: The Regulator may vary or revoke a Prohibition Order upon receiving an application from the individual named in the order. This action is discretionary and depends on the Regulator's assessment of all relevant circumstances. The individual must apply under the specified section of the FSMR to initiate this process. The Regulator does not usually impose a fixed duration for a Prohibition Order, as it is challenging to determine when an individual will become fit and proper again. Therefore, the application process is crucial for individuals seeking to alter the terms of their Prohibition Order. The Regulator's decision to vary or revoke the order will consider the individual's current fitness and propriety, among other factors, to ensure that the decision aligns with regulatory standards and public interest [#TGT:036cada9-f050-4c36-9c6c-bb8b3e741a75] and is permitted under the procedural guidelines [#SRC:5524af9d-0063-44a7-b9fd-5fd1d6bced7b].
rag_answer: The Regulator may vary or revoke a Prohibition Order if an individual applies for such a change, and it is within the Regulator's discretion to decide whether to grant the application. The key precondition is that the individual must be subject to a Prohibition Order, which is typically imposed when the Regulator determines that the individual is not a fit and proper person to perform any function related to a Regulated Activity carried out by an Authorised Person [#P:26b2f41c-bad9-4c1e-8c1b-a93ca35b6956]. The procedural step required is for the individual to apply under section 234(5) of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations (FSMR) to request the variation or revocation of the Prohibition Order [#P:5524af9d-0063-44a7-b9fd-5fd1d6bced7b]. The Regulator will then consider all relevant circumstances to determine whether to exercise its discretion to vary or revoke the order [#P:5524af9d-0063-44a7-b9fd-5fd1d6bced7b]. There are no specific timing or record-keeping requirements mentioned, but the decision is based on the Regulator's assessment of the individual's fitness and propriety at the time of the application.

question: How can someone get a Prohibition Order changed, and what does the Regulator need to decide?
gold_answer: To change a Prohibition Order, the person named in the order must apply to the Regulator. The Regulator can decide to change or cancel the order if they think it's right to do so. This decision is based on looking at all the important details about the person's situation. The Regulator doesn't usually set a time limit on these orders because it's hard to know when someone will be fit and proper again. So, if someone wants to change their order, they need to apply under the right section of the FSMR. The Regulator will then consider if the person is now fit and proper and if changing the order is in the public's best interest. This process allows the Regulator to ensure that any changes to the order are fair and appropriate [#TGT:036cada9-f050-4c36-9c6c-bb8b3e741a75] and follow the correct procedure [#SRC:5524af9d-0063-44a7-b9fd-5fd1d6bced7b].

The Regulator must then decide whether to impose, vary, or revoke the requirement, which in this context refers to the Prohibition Order [#P:fd3ba027-7a48-448f-b666-17a521bc47fe]. The decision-making process involves assessing whether the individual is a fit and proper person to perform any function related to a Regulated Activity carried out by an Authorised Person [#P:26b2f41c-bad9-4c1e-8c1b-a93ca35b6956]. There are no specific timing, record-keeping, or notification requirements mentioned in the provided context, nor are there any exceptions or edge cases explicitly stated. The process is contingent upon the individual's application and the Regulator's subsequent decision.

question: When can the Regulator choose to publish a decision notice and its details?
gold_answer: The Regulator can choose to publish a decision notice, final notice, or any other notice related to its powers, except for warning notices, whenever it sees fit. This includes sharing details about the matter the notice is about. The Regulator's ability to do this is supported by the FSMR, which allows for such publication when someone decides to take a decision to the Appeals Panel. This means the Regulator has the freedom to share important information about its decisions, helping to keep everyone informed about what actions are being taken. This discretionary power is important for ensuring that the Regulator's activities are transparent and that stakeholders are aware of the decisions being made. Therefore, the Regulator's choice to publish these notices is a key part of its role in maintaining oversight and accountability [#SRC:9ddabd85-89c9-44a4-a291-0388531f1314] and [#TGT:de87bb07-107e-4bc3-a834-8f7457702841].

[#P:de87bb07-107e-4bc3-a834-8f7457702841] The publication of such notices is not mandatory and is left to the Regulator's judgment, allowing it to decide based on the circumstances of each case. This discretion ensures that the Regulator can manage the transparency and confidentiality of its regulatory actions appropriately. There are no specific procedural steps or timing requirements mentioned in the context regarding when or how the publication should occur, indicating that the Regulator has flexibility in this aspect. However, it is implied that the decision to publish should be made in a manner consistent with the Regulator's overall regulatory objectives and responsibilities. [#P:de87bb07-107e-4bc3-a834-8f7457702841]

question: What must a firm ensure regarding its risk management systems, and what are the obligations of an Authorised Person in establishing and maintaining these systems?
gold_answer: A firm is required to ensure that its risk management systems provide the necessary means to identify, assess, mitigate, monitor, and control its risks. This obligation is crucial for the firm to effectively manage potential risks and align with regulatory expectations. Concurrently, an Authorised Person has the obligation to establish and maintain these risk management systems and controls. This involves not only setting up the systems but also ensuring their ongoing functionality to enable the identification, assessment, mitigation, control, and monitoring of risks. The dual requirement emphasizes the importance of both the initial establishment and the continuous maintenance of robust risk management frameworks. These frameworks are essential for managing risks effectively and ensuring compliance with regulatory standards [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1] and [#TGT:6f83c3c2-989d-47c2-952e-b1d8c7fb6c21].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person must ensure that its risk management systems are robust and effective, enabling it to identify, assess, mitigate, control, and monitor its risks. This is a fundamental obligation to ensure that the firm's affairs are managed effectively and responsibly by its senior management. The firm must establish and maintain comprehensive systems and controls, which include financial and risk management systems, to support this objective [#P:197353df-57d2-47ae-b918-6de51dee2ede]. Additionally, the risk management systems must be capable of implementing the firm's risk management policy, ensuring that all identified risks are appropriately managed [#P:f5f96dbf-c136-4047-bbcc-a4d0369677e6]. Furthermore, the firm is required to establish and maintain appropriate systems and controls specifically to manage its information security risk, highlighting the importance of safeguarding sensitive information [#P:e698f766-26b0-46ab-b4d0-bfda734cd4bf]. These obligations collectively ensure that the firm operates within a framework that prioritizes risk management and information security, thereby supporting its overall operational integrity and compliance with regulatory requirements.

question: What do firms need to do to make sure their risk management systems work well, and what should an Authorised Person do to keep these systems running?
gold_answer: Firms need to make sure their risk management systems can identify, assess, mitigate, monitor, and control risks effectively. This means they have to check that their systems are set up to handle any risks that might come up. At the same time, an Authorised Person has to set up and keep these systems running smoothly. This involves not just starting the systems but also making sure they keep working well over time. Both the firm and the Authorised Person have important roles in making sure the risk management systems are effective and meet regulatory requirements. This helps in managing risks properly and staying compliant with the rules [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1] and [#TGT:6f83c3c2-989d-47c2-952e-b1d8c7fb6c21].
rag_answer:
To ensure that their risk management systems function effectively, firms must establish and maintain systems and controls that allow them to identify, assess, mitigate, control, and monitor their risks. An Authorised Person is required to ensure that these systems are capable of implementing specific risk policies, such as Market Risk and Operational Risk policies. This involves several key steps: 

- An Authorised Person must ensure that its risk management systems enable the implementation of the Market Risk policy, allowing for the identification, assessment, mitigation, control, and monitoring of Market Risk. [#P:e189cb84-fae2-44ab-ab9f-83413475fa73]
- Similarly, the systems must support the implementation of the Operational Risk policy, ensuring the same comprehensive risk management process. [#P:4ddb2ccf-d881-4084-841f-0613d60d7c29]
- The policies must be reviewed and updated at intervals appropriate to the nature, scale, and complexity of the firm's activities, ensuring they remain effective and relevant. [#P:e189cb84-fae2-44ab-ab9f-83413475fa73][#P:4ddb2ccf-d881-4084-841f-0613d60d7c29]
- Overall, the systems must be robust enough to implement the risk management policy effectively. [#P:f5f96dbf-c136-4047-bbcc-a4d0369677e6]

By adhering to these requirements, firms can maintain effective risk management systems that are responsive to their operational needs and regulatory obligations.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator cancel a Financial Services Permission for an Authorised Person, and how does this relate to the Regulator's own initiative powers?
gold_answer: The Regulator may cancel a Financial Services Permission for an Authorised Person if certain conditions are met. Specifically, the Regulator can exercise this power if the Authorised Person is failing, or is likely to fail, to satisfy the Threshold Condition Rules, has committed a contravention of the Regulations or any associated Rules, has not carried on a Regulated Activity for at least 12 months, or if it is deemed desirable to further the Regulator's objectives. This aligns with the Regulator's ability to act on its own initiative, where it may cancel or vary a Financial Services Permission if any of these circumstances apply. The Regulator's initiative allows it to add or remove activities from the Permission or adjust descriptions without broadening them, and even to include provisions as if a new Permission were being sought. This ensures that the Regulator can maintain oversight and enforce compliance effectively, using its powers to address any potential or actual failures by Authorised Persons [#SRC:cd2e3201-9c8d-41db-ae9e-c56f0e181dcb] and [#TGT:702ea9bb-da70-4ea7-91e8-a693eb99447b].
rag_answer: The Regulator may cancel a Financial Services Permission for an Authorised Person under specific conditions. Firstly, the cancellation can occur upon the application of the Authorised Person itself, indicating a voluntary relinquishment of the permission [#P:ce1b672f-6101-4c70-ba07-fa975f7b8fe4]. Additionally, if a variation of the Financial Services Permission results in the Authorised Person no longer having any Regulated Activities for which the permission is required, the Regulator must cancel the permission once it is satisfied that maintaining it is unnecessary [#P:eb7ff00a-76e3-4a07-b17e-ff39f661dde0]. This cancellation process is part of the Regulator's initiative powers, allowing it to ensure that permissions are only held by entities actively engaged in regulated activities. The Regulator's decision to cancel under these circumstances is contingent upon its satisfaction that the permission is redundant, ensuring that regulatory oversight is appropriately aligned with the Authorised Person's current activities [#P:bf5d6dcd-039b-4be7-9385-fc2d0bd19a55].

question: When can the Regulator cancel a Financial Services Permission for an Authorised Person, and how does this relate to their own powers?
gold_answer: The Regulator can cancel a Financial Services Permission for an Authorised Person if certain conditions are met. This helps the Regulator keep control and make sure Authorised Persons follow the rules [#SRC:cd2e3201-9c8d-41db-ae9e-c56f0e181dcb] and [#TGT:702ea9bb-da70-4ea7-91e8-a693eb99447b].

These provisions collectively empower the Regulator to maintain the integrity of the financial services environment by ensuring that permissions are only held by entities actively conducting regulated activities.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator withdraw an Approval for a Controlled Function, and how does this relate to the fitness and propriety of the Approved Person?
gold_answer: The Regulator is permitted to withdraw an Approval for a Controlled Function if it determines that the individual is not fit and proper to perform the function. This decision can be based on several factors, such as breaches of obligations, bankruptcy, criminal convictions, or findings that question the individual's integrity, honesty, or capability to manage affairs due to mental or physical incapacity. Additionally, the withdrawal can occur if the individual or their firm requests it. The Regulator's authority to withdraw such Approval is grounded in the need to ensure that only those who meet the required standards of fitness and propriety are allowed to perform Controlled Functions. This ensures that the integrity of the financial system is maintained and that individuals in these roles are capable and trustworthy. The Regulator's decision-making process involves assessing whether the circumstances align with the criteria that would render an individual unfit or improper for the role, as required [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554] and permitted [#SRC:0f70ac0b-8f1a-48d4-83d8-35cd6b2b1dbb].
rag_answer: The Regulator may withdraw an Approval for a Controlled Function if it determines that the individual is not a fit and proper person to perform the Controlled Function in question. This decision is based on the assessment of the individual's fitness and propriety, which is a key precondition for both granting and maintaining such Approval. [#P:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554] Before an application for a Controlled Function is lodged, the Authorised Person must conduct reasonable enquiries into the individual's fitness and propriety, ensuring that the individual is suitable for the role. [#P:bb10eb21-ffc9-4c7b-9520-8f6898afb8b1] Additionally, the Regulator or relevant Authorised Person will only authorise an individual to perform multiple Controlled Functions if they are satisfied with the individual's fitness and propriety for each function. [#P:1a70ac45-3c06-4ea9-899f-aa4c1d91f4c0] This comprehensive assessment process underscores the importance of maintaining high standards for individuals in Controlled Functions, ensuring that only those who are fit and proper continue to hold such positions.

question: Under what conditions may the Regulator exercise its initiative power to vary an Approved Person's status, and what procedural steps must be followed if the Regulator decides to withdraw the Controlled Function Approval?
gold_answer: The Regulator may exercise its initiative power to vary the Approval of an Approved Person in various circumstances, such as when the individual has not demonstrated the required level of skill, care, and diligence, or if their conduct does not align with the expected standards. Additionally, if there are concerns regarding the Approved Person's ability or suitability to perform the Controlled Function as initially approved, the Regulator may take action. However, these concerns must not be severe enough to necessitate the withdrawal of the person's status based on fitness or propriety. In cases where the Regulator determines that the individual is not a fit and proper person to perform the Controlled Function, the Regulator may proceed to withdraw the Approval granted under section 45. This withdrawal process is a formal procedure that ensures the individual's status is revoked when they fail to meet the necessary criteria for performing their role effectively [#SRC:61383442-b7af-4486-ab5c-610a613f73a2] [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554].
rag_answer: The Regulator may exercise its initiative power to vary an Approved Person's status under certain conditions, such as when the individual has not demonstrated the expected level of skill, care, and diligence in their role, when their conduct is inconsistent with the standards expected, or when there are concerns about their ability or suitability to perform the Controlled Functions as originally approved, though not to the extent of withdrawing their status based on fitness or propriety [#P:61383442-b7af-4486-ab5c-610a613f73a2]. If the Regulator decides to withdraw the Controlled Function Approval, the Authorised Person must submit a request to the Regulator in a prescribed form, detailing any circumstances that suggest the individual is no longer fit and proper [#P:a7498f9b-4c45-4e0d-bbcb-9b0c83edf86b]. This process ensures that the Regulator is informed of any issues affecting the individual's suitability and allows for a formal review of their status. The Regulator's decision to vary or withdraw an Approved Person's status is guided by the need to maintain high standards of conduct and competence within the financial services sector.

question: When can the Regulator change an Approved Person's status, and what happens if they decide to take away the Controlled Function Approval?
gold_answer: The Regulator can change an Approved Person's status if they haven't shown the needed skill, care, and diligence, or if their behavior doesn't meet the expected standards. If there are worries about their ability or suitability for the role, the Regulator might act, but only if these worries aren't serious enough to take away their status for not being fit and proper. If the Regulator decides that the person isn't fit and proper to do the job, they can take away the Approval given under section 45. This means the person can no longer perform the Controlled Function because they don't meet the necessary standards for the role [#SRC:61383442-b7af-4486-ab5c-610a613f73a2] [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554].

If the Regulator decides to withdraw the Controlled Function Approval, the Authorised Person must notify the Regulator in writing within 10 days of the withdrawal or variation [#P:05635b20-d9cb-455a-ab85-cc8d86512224]. This ensures that the Regulator is kept informed of changes in the status of individuals performing Controlled Functions, maintaining the integrity and proper functioning of the regulatory framework.

question: What requirements must an Authorised Person fulfill when applying for a Financial Services Permission to conduct a Regulated Activity with a Retail Client?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person applying for a Financial Services Permission to conduct a Regulated Activity with or for a Retail Client must meet several specific requirements. These include having adequate systems and controls in place to carry out the Regulated Activities effectively. Additionally, the applicant must ensure compliance with the requirements in COBS relevant to Retail Clients through appropriate systems, controls, policies, and procedures. It is also essential that the applicant maintains systems and controls to ensure that its Employees are competent and capable of performing their assigned functions, especially those involving dealings with Retail Clients. Furthermore, the applicant must have adequate complaints handling policies and procedures to address any issues that may arise. These obligations are critical to ensuring that the applicant can responsibly manage the services provided to Retail Clients, as required [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] and permitted [#SRC:1ad61409-a8d2-40b0-82f6-0ab30250c45a].

Additionally, the applicant must establish adequate systems and controls, including policies and procedures, to ensure compliance with the Conduct of Business Rules (COBS) relevant to Retail Clients [#P:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884]. question: What must an Authorised Person do to get permission to do a Regulated Activity with a Retail Client?
